conclusion: To find the maximum value of the electromotive force (EMF) generated by the AC generator, we need to use the relationship between the magnetic flux and the induced EMF.
The EMF induced in a coil rotating in a magnetic field is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = -N \frac{d\Phi}{dt} \).
\( \mathcal{E} \) is the induced EMF, \( N \) is the number of turns of the coil, \( \Phi \) is the magnetic flux through the coil.
Given that the magnetic flux \(\Phi\) varies sinusoidally with time, we can express it as: \( \Phi(t) = \Phi_0 \sin(\omega t) \).
\( \Phi_0 \) is the maximum magnetic flux, \( \omega \) is the angular frequency of the rotation.
The maximum value of the EMF occurs when the rate of change of the magnetic flux is at its maximum.
This happens when the derivative of \(\Phi(t)\) with respect to time is at its maximum value.
The maximum value of \(\cos(\omega t)\) is 1, so the maximum rate of change of the magnetic flux is \( \left( \frac{d\Phi}{dt} \right)_{\text{max}} = \Phi_0 \omega \).
Therefore, the maximum EMF is \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = N \Phi_0 \omega \).
From the graph in Figure (Z), the maximum value of \(\Phi\) is \(2.0 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{Wb}\).
The period \(T\) of the sinusoidal variation can be found from the graph, which is \(6.28 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{s}\).
The angular frequency \(\omega\) is related to the period by \(\omega = \frac{2\pi}{T}\).
